speaker: James
text: [dry] "The energy revolution isn't about saving the planet, Elena. Nor national security. It's about pure economics."

speaker: Elena
text: [frustrated] "Oh, come on, James. That's a terribly cynical take. Are you really dismissing climate change *again*?"

speaker: James
text: "History Future Now has previously stated we've missed that boat. The article makes it clear: arguing about climate change is a waste of time."

speaker: Elena
text: "So we just give up? That's not exactly a rallying cry for action, is it?"

speaker: James
text: "It's realism. The main driver for solar is its cost. It's simply too cheap."

speaker: Elena
text: "But it's been heavily subsidised, hasn't it? That's hardly 'cheap' in a free market sense."

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] "That's changing. Rapidly. The raw material is silicon—sand. Manufacturing techniques are improving constantly."

speaker: Elena
text: "Even so, what about intermittency? The sun doesn't always shine when you need power."

speaker: James
text: "Irrelevant for the core problem it creates. Solar produces its peak output exactly when demand surges: midday."

speaker: Elena
text: "Okay, but that doesn't mean conventional power stations just… vanish."

speaker: James
text: "Their profits do. Think of the 'merit order' in electricity generation. Spot prices are set by the most expensive generator online."

speaker: Elena
text: "Right, so during peak demand, prices go up, and everyone profits."

speaker: James
text: "Exactly. That's where conventional generators make their money. But solar has zero fuel costs, almost zero marginal cost."

speaker: Elena
text: "So it always undercuts them."

speaker: James
text: "Always. Deutsche Bank analysts found solar PV was cutting peak electricity prices by up to 40%."

speaker: Elena
text: [surprised] "Forty percent? Wait, when did that happen?"

speaker: James
text: "Germany, years ago. Utilities found it 'intolerable'. Enel, Italy's biggest utility, saw a one-third slump in earnings from generation."

speaker: Elena
text: "One-third? That's... actually devastating for their business model."

speaker: James
text: "It is. And it's not just the wholesale market. There's a second problem."

speaker: Elena
text: "You mean domestic rooftop solar? Eating into their retail profits?"

speaker: James
text: "Yes. Households switching means fewer retail customers paying higher prices. The cost of grid maintenance gets spread across a smaller base."

speaker: Elena
text: "Leaving those without solar to pay more. Creating more incentive to switch. It's a death spiral for utilities, isn't it?"

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] "Precisely. A 'musical chairs' scenario, as the article puts it. The music stops eventually."

speaker: Elena
text: "But incumbents fight back. They have political influence. You said that yourself, even in 'Green Is Not Red, But Blue'."

speaker: James
text: "True. But against the falling costs of sand? Good luck. Planning permission for a new conventional power station takes 3-7 years."

speaker: Elena
text: "And solar is much quicker to deploy."

speaker: James
text: "Much. Does it make sense to build a new coal plant today if it'll be economically unviable within a few years of operation?"

speaker: Elena
text: "No... I suppose not. You're saying the investment case collapses before it's even built."

speaker: James
text: "For companies like GE, who make those generators, their business has a finite life. The same for coal and gas companies."

speaker: Elena
text: "And then oil? You're going to tell me oil is next, aren't you?"

speaker: James
text: "Electric vehicles are a perfect companion to solar. Parked all day, charging cheaply. This revolution will affect oil within a decade."

speaker: Elena
text: "Within a decade? I think that's wildly optimistic, frankly. There are billions of conventional cars in developing countries alone."

speaker: James
text: "The trend is set. Remember when you called it a 'death spiral'? It applies to fossil fuels too."

speaker: Elena
text: I don't want to agree with you on this, James, but the numbers, especially Enel's earnings slump, don't leave much room to manoeuvre. It’s... cold hard capitalism in action. That's a brutal reality.

speaker: James
text: [amused] "Indeed. As we often say, 'Green is not red, but blue'. Environmentalism driven by market forces, not ideology."

speaker: Elena
text: "So, the losers are anyone invested in the old system. And the winners are... pension funds owning solar farms."

speaker: James
text: "And industrial consumers enjoying cheaper peak power. The everyday person who installs panels, too."

speaker: Elena
text: "But what about grid stability? If everyone's generating their own, who pays for the balancing act, the infrastructure?"

speaker: James
text: "A very good question. One that existing utilities are desperate to answer, because it's their last bastion of revenue."

speaker: Elena
text: "So it's not quite a clean sweep. There are still deep structural challenges ahead."

speaker: James
text: "Lingering challenges, yes. But the direction of travel is undeniable. The market has decided."

speaker: Elena
text: "Well, that's harder to argue with than I expected. But it's a brutal revolution, isn't it? Just pure efficiency, leaving whole industries stranded."

speaker: James
text: "History is full of such revolutions. The steam engine, the internal combustion engine. This is just the next one."

speaker: Elena
text: "And we're just... observing the wreckage."

speaker: James
text: "Or deciding where to stand when the music stops."
